subject: Art
title: Type Classification
description: The major categories of typefaces and their personalities.

hook.text: Beyond serif and sans-serif, there's a whole taxonomy of type. Each category has a personality, a history, and ideal use cases. Knowing them is like knowing genres in music â€” it helps you choose the right one.

buildup.text: Major classes: Old Style serifs (Garamond â€” elegant, bookish), Transitional (Times â€” neutral, authoritative), Modern/Didone (Bodoni â€” high contrast, fashion), Slab (Rockwell â€” bold, mechanical), Geometric sans (Futura â€” precise), Humanist sans (Gill Sans â€” warm), Script (flowing, handwritten), Display (decorative, for headlines).

discovery.text: Each class carries cultural associations: Old Style = literature, history. Modern = luxury, fashion. Geometric = technology, precision. Slab = strength, vintage. Script = elegance, personal touch. Display = uniqueness, branding.

twist.text: Many iconic brands are defined by their type classification: Vogue uses Didone (high fashion). Apple uses a geometric/grotesque sans (clean tech). The New York Times uses Blackletter (tradition, authority). The typeface IS the brand.

climax.text: Next time you see a logo or poster, identify the type classification. Understanding why that class was chosen reveals the message behind the message â€” the personality that typography silently communicates.

punchline.text: Every typeface has a personality. Match the personality to the message.
